unkerpaulie

there are those that believe in God and accept evolution. one of the most common definitions of God is Creator. in fact, "Creator" and "God" are in most cases synonymous and interchangable.
 
 if evolution (and by extension, spontaneous origin) is true, can God create? is there anything that God has created?
shackelfordster

Some argue that God can create, did create, and only created the Big Bang and the fundamental laws of physics and the universe, and that everything else has progressed according to those laws. Some say that God is a personification of those laws. One fundamentalist I spoke with called the Strong Nuclear Force "Jesus."
 
 Can the New Testament God create? No. He was created by man to explain what already existed using the values and knowledge of the literate religious people of that time.
Demon38

if evolution (and by extension, spontaneous origin) is true, can God create? is there anything that God has created?
 
 
 When I was Christian, I had no problem with this. Evolution and abiogenesis were true, all phenomenon can be explained by natural causes. There were no gaps that could only be explained by the supernatural, so science is never undermined. And yet, God is omnipotent. All these natural processes were created, controlled and guided by Him. His hand sure and strong guiding our destiny, yet completely undetectable. If it wasn't undetectable, what good was faith?
Alan Ryan

When I was Christian, I had no problem with this. Evolution and abiogenesis were true, all phenomenon can be explained by natural causes. There were no gaps that could only be explained by the supernatural, so science is never undermined. And yet, God is omnipotent. All these natural processes were created, controlled and guided by Him. His hand sure and strong guiding our destiny, yet completely undetectable. If it wasn't undetectable, what good was faith?

 
 If, as I believe Christian scientists are obliged to maintain, God anticipated Darwin and the evolution of the species etc. is part of his "plan", he must also have anticipated Newton, Einstein, Heisenberg, etc. etc. What I mean here is that as the eternal and omnipotent Intelligent Designer he is also understood to be the first cause that set the universe rolling from the precise moment of the Big Bang. To do this he must have already possessed the Grand Unified Theory which is supposed to unite all the laws and forces of physics in one ultimate elegant equation. All natural phenomena from the most subtle quantum fluctuation to the most complex motions of the natural world were thus originated in his "mind" before the beginning of time.
 
 I once asked a priest if he ever thought about God in this way: he said he had to admit that when probed at the ultimate level, he was content to say that God is a divine "mystery". 
 Once people retreat from questions raised in a rational enquiry by resorting to answers cloaked with "mysteries", I suspect they are on very weak ground.
Tigerlilly

Some argue that God can create, did create, and only created the Big Bang and the fundamental laws of physics and the universe, and that everything else has progressed according to those laws. Some say that God is a personification of those laws. One fundamentalist I spoke with called the Strong Nuclear Force "Jesus."
 
 Can the New Testament God create? No. He was created by man to explain what already existed using the values and knowledge of the literate religious people of that time.

 
 WHy would anyone add such a superflouous entity like God? The razor shaves off nonsensical metaphysical entites quite easily.
 
 We don't need to say God created nature, the laws, or anything, since you can appeal to what we can observe, verify, and falsify to already explain it.
 
 God is unfalsifiable as an entity, therefore worthless.
unkerpaulie

When I was Christian, I had no problem with this. Evolution and abiogenesis were true, all phenomenon can be explained by natural causes. There were no gaps that could only be explained by the supernatural, so science is never undermined. And yet, God is omnipotent. All these natural processes were created, controlled and guided by Him. His hand sure and strong guiding our destiny, yet completely undetectable. If it wasn't undetectable, what good was faith?

 the problem is, would the laws of physics hold if God didnt exist? with God's invisible and undetectible "guidance", would opposite eletrical charges still attract? would light still travel at the same speed? would applied forces always be equal in opposite directions?
 
 if God's invisible, undetectible "guidance" is not necessary to "babysit" the laws of nature and make sure they remain constant, then is there anything in the physical universe we need God for?
jim's trucking

...
 
 I once asked a priest if he ever thought about God in this way: he said he had to admit that when probed at the ultimate level, he was content to say that God is a divine "mystery". 
 Once people retreat from questions raised in a rational enquiry by resorting to answers cloaked with "mysteries", I suspect they are on very weak ground.
I don't agree with the "weak ground" conclusion.
 
 I doubt there is a single person that knows the answer to every question there is in any one significant field.
 
 Thinking of God with man's intellect is entertaining but futile. Were we able to understand everything about God, we would be equal, therefore God...which we ain't.
 
 There's nothing we can do about the mystery unless it is someday explained to us by God.
 
 I am one that believes in creation and evolution. God created it all and let it happen naturally rather than suddenly casting or forging each item overnight. 
 
 I believe man put the timetable on things just to be able to explain it to others. It is extremely difficult, even with our current understanding of numbers and time to visualize a timespan of 30 million years. 
 
 It's hard to believe that Cuba was once in the Pacific Ocean. It's hard to understand how the present continents could have once been contiguous or that some moutain ranges were pushed up from smooth "flat" plates.
 
 The timeline of the existence of breathing mammals is but a spec in time. Man's existence is but a mini-spec on that spec.
 
 To answer the original question, God created it all. He knew what would happen before it happened and He let it happen.
Alan Ryan

if God's invisible, undetectible "guidance" is not necessary to "babysit" the laws of nature and make sure they remain constant, then is there anything in the physical universe we need God for?

 
 No: God is not scientifically necessary.
Alan Ryan

I don't agree with the "weak ground" conclusion.
 
 To answer the original question, God created it all. He knew what would happen before it happened and He let it happen.

 
 If that's what you choose to believe, then I'm not the kind of "militant atheist" who would wish to disturb your convictions. 
 
 I'm content merely to record my disbelief in the "mystery" of God's works or in God himself - and to give reasons for my disbelief.
jim's trucking

If that's what you choose to believe, then I'm not the kind of "militant atheist" who would wish to disturb your convictions. 
 
 I'm content merely to record my disbelief in the "mystery" of God's works or in God himself - and to give reasons for my disbelief.
...but you explain your beliefs (or non-beliefs) with man's logic. I contend that man's logic is insufficient. We will likely never understand God totally. We are incapable of doing so.
 
 Try as you may, you will likely never disturb my convictions. They may change, but it won't be your doing.
unkerpaulie

...but you explain your beliefs (or non-beliefs) with man's logic. I contend that man's logic is insufficient. We will likely never understand God totally. We are incapable of doing so.

 i take it you realize that "man's logic" is the only tool capable of helping us determine truth from false. even is there is a higher logic, such as "God's logic", it can never help us determine the truth about something, since it is unavailable to us. all we have to work with is plain old man's logic.
 
 if God is absolutely true, wouldnt this truth be determinable for all "logics"?
Alan Ryan

...but you explain your beliefs (or non-beliefs) with man's logic. I contend that man's logic is insufficient. We will likely never understand God totally. We are incapable of doing so.
 
 Try as you may, you will likely never disturb my convictions. They may change, but it won't be your doing.

 
 You seem to have misunderstood: I said I would NOT WISH to disturb your convictions.
jim's trucking

You seem to have misunderstood: I said I would NOT WISH to disturb your convictions.
My bad. emoticon_wow That is what you said.
jim's trucking

i take it you realize that "man's logic" is the only tool capable of helping us determine truth from false. even is there is a higher logic, such as "God's logic", it can never help us determine the truth about something, since it is unavailable to us. all we have to work with is plain old man's logic.
 
 if God is absolutely true, wouldnt this truth be determinable for all "logics"?
I realize that man's logic is the only thinking tool we have. Even our computers, with all their power and speed were built and programmed according to man's logic.
 
 I don't know that God's logic differs much from ours. I do know that it's hard to conceive of omniscience and omnipotence, but that doesn't make them impossibilities. 
 
 Man should not be so vain as to think that just because something can't be understood it can't exist. This is the stuff of fools.
 
 One may have many varied reasons for not believing in God, but a lack of understanding is not a valid one.
 
 I do not understand how someone could be truly evil, but evil people do exist.

title: 4Forums.com Political Debates and Polls -  can God create?
